Graphical abstract MoS2 catalysts with higher exposure of active sites, which result from its less stacking layers and smaller lateral sizes, demonstrate higher catalytic activities for the slurry-phase hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Slurry-phase hydrogenation technology is the frontier topic in the efficient conversion of heavy oils into light fractions around the world. Developing highly active dispersed MoS2 catalysts is the major obstacle to realize the industrial application of upgrading heavy oils. In this work, both top-down ball-milling method and bottom-up hydrothermal method were designed to synthesize MoS2 catalysts with controllable layer structures. The stacking layers and lateral sizes for micro-scaled MoS2 catalysts by ball-milling method can be reduced to their limits and stabilize at 6 ∼ 8 layers and lateral size of ca. 30 nm. The more flexible bottom-up hydrothermal method can construct MoS2 catalysts with much smaller lateral sizes and fewer stacking layers, especially, MoS2 catalyst fabricated with ammonium tetrathiomolybdate as Mo and S precursor possesses average stacking layers of 2 and lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons anthracene, phenanthrene and naphthalene were used as model compounds of heavy oils to investigate the catalytic hydrogenation performance of designed MoS2 catalysts. The catalytic activities of MoS2 catalysts can be well correlated with their stacking layers and lateral size. The edges of top and bottom S-Mo-S atomic layers for MoS2 sheets, named rim sites, are positively correlated with the exposure of active sites for catalytic hydrogenation of PAHs. The highest catalytic activity of MoS2 catalyst results from its layer structures of 100% rim sites and the smallest lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm, which is beneficial to expose maximum active sites for catalytic hydrogenation reactions. This work can guide us to design the highly active hydrogenation catalysts, and promote the industrial application of upgrading heavy oils. Keywords MoS2 Active sites Catalytic hydrogenation Slurry-phase Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons 1 Introduction Upgrading of heavy oils has attracted extensive attention because of rising global energy demand and diminishing good quality fossil fuel reserves. In order to defeat the setbacks, various processes such as carbon rejection or hydrogen addition have been explored and researched in the past few decades to upgrade low-value heavy oils into light and high-value fuels [1,2]. Catalytic hydroconversion is a more effective approach to upgrade heavy oils into liquid transportation fuels for modern refinery [3–5]. Various hydrogenation reactor technologies, which adopt fixed-bed [6,7], ebullated-bed [8], moving-bed [9] and slurry-phase reactors [10] have been designed to perform the hydroconversion of heavy oils [1,11]. Hydroconversion with fixed-bed, ebullated-bed or moving-bed reactors often has an unfavorable problem of catalyst deactivation resulting from coking and heavy metal deposition, especially for the hydroprocessing of heavier feedstocks [12]. Besides, the critical problems such as diffusion of feedstocks, pressure drop and mass transfer also exist in fixed-bed, ebullated-bed or moving-bed reactors [13]. The limitations in the above processes can be overwhelmed with slurry-phase hydrogenation reactor. Recently, the slurry-phase hydrogenation has been the frontier topic in the efficient conversion of heavy oils into light fractions. The challenge of hydrogenation technology with slurry-phase reactor is developing efficient catalysts to hydrogenate rapidly the heaviest fraction, asphaltenes, to achieve the total hydroconversion of heavy oils [14,15]. Among the reported catalysts such as Mo-, Ni-, Co–, and Fe-based catalysts for hydroconversion of heavy oils, dispersed MoS2 catalysts exhibit the optimized catalytic activities of heavy oil hydrogenation [10,16]. Due to their unique layered structures and special electronic properties, two-dimensional layered MoS2 materials have been previously studied and applied in many fields, such as catalysis [17–20], batteries [21], solid lubricants [22], photovoltaics [23], sensors [24], and electronic transistors [25]. In hexagonal MoS2 crystals, one Mo atomic layer is sandwiched by two S atomic layers. Bulk 2H-MoS2 materials are formed by the van der Waals interactions among S layers along the c axis. The basal planes of 2H-MoS2 are inert, whereas edges accommodate catalytic active centers [26]. However, the exposed active edges of bulk MoS2 for catalysis reactions are very limited. So the synthesis of MoS2 catalysts with more exposed active edges is an effective strategy to boost their catalytic activities. In order to enhance the exposed edges of MoS2, it is essential to develop the alternatives of an efficient fabrication method to tailor its layer structures and lateral dimension. Various synthesis methods of both top-down and bottom-up approaches have been employed to fabricate MoS2 with few stacking layers and small lateral sizes in order to achieve the superior performance. In recent years, the fabrication methods of single- and few-layer MoS2 materials mainly focused on the top-down exfoliation of bulk materials [27], including mechanical cleavage [28], chemical exfoliation [29,30], liquid phase exfoliation [31], and laser thinning techniques [32]. By breaking the van der Waals interactions of MoS2 interlayer, the top-down exfoliation process is very effective for thinning bulk MoS2 into single- and few-layer MoS2 microsheets to enhance the exposure of edges. But the top-down exfoliation process cannot break the chemical bonds in a single S-Mo-S atomic layer to shrink the lateral dimension of MoS2 microsheets into nano-scaled MoS2 sheets to further increase the exposed edges. However, the exposure of edges for MoS2 materials can be accurately adjusted by weakening van der Waals interactions and controllably constructing chemical bonds using the bottom-up chemical synthesis. Kibsgaard et al. reported triangularly shaped MoS2 nanoclusters with the size-dependent structure obtained by optimizing the sulphur dosage. MoS2 nanoclusters with low stacking numbers and small lateral sizes can expose a large fraction of active edges and then improve the catalysis performance [33]. Xie et al. reported defect-rich MoS2 nanosheets with additional exposed active edges through adding excess S precursor, and the defect-rich MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets exhibited enhanced activities of electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution [34]. Our previous work reported MoS2 catalysts with highly exposed active edges including MoS2 nanoflowers fabricated by tuning the Mo precursors [35], MoS2 nanosheets prepared by controlling the crystallization time [36], mono-dispersed MoS2 nanospheres synthesized with surfactant assistance [37], and MoS2 nanocatalysts obtained by tuning the S precursors [19]. All the above MoS2 catalysts synthesized with hydrothermal/solvothermal method exhibit better catalytic activities of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons hydrogenation and heavy oils during the slurry-phase reaction. Consequently, both the top-down and bottom-up synthesis approaches can fabricate MoS2 materials with highly exposed edges, and efficiently improve their catalytic performances. Herein, MoS2 samples with controllable edge exposures were designed and synthesized with top-down approach by ball milling of bulk commercial MoS2 for different times and bottom-up hydrothermal approach using different Mo and S precursors. The results of characterizations turn out that ball milling method can tailor bulk micro-scaled MoS2 sheets into nano-scaled lateral dimension and less stacking layers, and that hydrothermal method can construct MoS2 with much smaller lateral sizes and fewer stacking layers. Catalytic hydrogenation activities of MoS2 samples were evaluated with a slurry-phase reactor using polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons anthracene, phenanthrene and naphthalene as model compounds of heavy oils. The structure–activity relationship between the structures of MoS2 catalysts and catalytic activities of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons hydrogenation was discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All the analytical grade chemicals were used in this work without any purification. Commercial bulk MoS2 and tridecane were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Thioacetamide (CH3CSNH2, AR) was supplied by Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Industry Research Institute. Ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Denoted as AHM, AR), ammonium sulfide ((NH4)2S, 8.0 wt% S), molybdenum oxide (MoO3), and sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4) were supplied by Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Company. Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate ((NH4)2MoS4, Denoted as ATTM) was home-made according to the literature [38]. Potassium thiocyanate (KSCN, AR) was supplied by Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. Sodium sulfide (Na2S, AR) was provided by Shanghai Tongya Chemical Factory. Model compounds anthracene (C14H10, AR), phenanthrene (C14H10, AR), and naphthalene (C10H8, AR) were purchased from J&K Scientific. 2.2 Synthesis of MoS2 samples MoS2 samples synthesized by top-down method were obtained by ball milling of commercial MoS2 (Mc) for different times. Typically, 1.0 g of Mc powder was put into agate jars of 50 mL with agate balls, and milled on a planetary miller with revolution speed of 500 rpm. for 2 ∼ 16 h, and the obtained MoS2 after ball milling for X h was denoted as BM X . MoS2 samples synthesized by bottom-up method were achieved by hydrothermal process with different Mo and S precursors. Mo precursors, S precursors and reductants were dissolved in demineralized water to generate a homogenous solution. Hydrazinehydrate was used as the reductant, and hydrochloric acid or ammonia was used to tune the pH value of the above solution. Detailed information of MoS2 catalysts synthesized by tuning the Mo and S precursors is given in Table 1 . The resulting solutions were transferred into four 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves, and then the autoclaves were sealed tightly. Hydrothermal reactions were carried out at 200 °C for 24 h. After that, the autoclaves were cooled down to room temperature naturally. The black precipitates were filtered, washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol, and finally dried at 70 °C overnight in a vacuum oven. The obtained MoS2 samples were named as HT x-y , herein × and y respectively represent the average stacking layer number and the lateral size of MoS2 catalyst. 2.3 Characterizations of MoS2 samples X-ray power diffraction (XRD) patterns of MoS2 samples were taken with a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on a JEM 2100 instrument. Raman spectra were collected with a Raman spectrometer (Senterra) with a 532 nm excitation laser. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded on a VG ESCALAB MK2 spectrometer with the reference of C 1 s peak (284.6 eV). BET surface areas were recorded with an ASAP 2420 equipment from Micromeritics. 2.4 Catalytic performance of MoS2 catalysts The catalytic hydrogenation performance of MoS2 sample was evaluated with a 100 mL Parr high pressure autoclave. 30 g tridecane, 3 g anthracene(AN) / phenanthrene(PN) / naphthalene(NA) and 0.075 g MoS2 catalyst were added in the autoclave. After discharging air with H2 for 3 times, for AN / PN hydrogenation reaction, the autoclave was charged with H2 to 8.0 MPa at room temperature, and then elevated to 350 °C at 10 °C/min. The reactions of AN and PN hydrogenation were kept at 350 °C for 4 h at the stirring rate of 300 rpm.. The NA hydrogenation reaction was performed with the initial hydrogen pressure of 6.0 MPa, and kept at 300 °C for 6 h. The autoclave was cooled naturally, and the reaction mixtures were filtered to remove MoS2 catalyst and obtain liquid products. The liquid products were qualitatively and quantitatively analyzed with an Agilent 7890B/5977A GC/MS and an Agilent 7890A GC system, respectively. According to the results GC–MS, the hydrogenation reactions of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) proceed successively, and the hydrogenation products were shown in Scheme 1 . PAHs were first hydrogenated into preliminary products, and then further hydrogenated to full saturation. Only trace hydrocracking products can be detected. These isomers can be denoted as one compound. The number in the hydrogenation product represents the number of hydrogen atoms added in PAHs. In the hydrogenation products, the quantitative analysis of conversion and selectivity of each product is calculated assuming the carbon balance before and after the hydrogenation reaction. The hydrogenation selectivity (S) of certain product in the hydrogenation products of PAHs is the ratio between the GC peak area of certain product and the total GC peak area for all the hydrogenation products, and is calculated according to Eq. From Fig. 1a, the diffraction peaks at 14.4°, 32.7°, 39.6°, 58.4°, etc. in the XRD pattern of MC are very sharp, and can be correspondingly indexed to (002), (100), (103), (110), etc. planes of hexagonal 2H-MoS2 (JCPDS No. 37–1492). The (002) diffraction peak at 2θ = 14.4° corresponds to the interlayer distance of 6.2 Å. MoS2 samples obtained by ball milling of Mc from 2 h to 16 h can keep its pristine 2H-MoS2 phase of Mc sample, and have no expansion of the interlayer distance. When the ball milling time is prolonged from 2 h to 12 h, the intensities of diffraction peaks, especially (002) peak, in the XRD patterns of the obtained MoS2 samples firstly decrease gradually, and then essentially maintains constant as the ball milling time prolonging to 16 h. It can be speculated that the particle size and crystallinity can level off with enough ball-milling time, e.g. longer than 12 h. XRD patterns of MoS2 samples synthesized by hydrothermal method with different Mo and S precursors (Fig. 1b) show obviously weak and broad peaks at about 2θ = 8.9°, 17.5°, 32.0° and 58.0°, indicating their poor crystalinity. The latter two diffraction peaks can be assigned to (100) and (110) planes of 2H-MoS2. The former twos at 2θ = 8.9°and 17.5° result from the splitting of (002) diffraction peak, and correspond to the interlayer distance of 9.9 Å, which differs from the (002) diffraction peak at 14.4° of 2H-MoS2 with the interlayer distance of 6.2 Å. According to the results reported in the literatures and our previous works [35–37,39], the change of interlayer distances may result from the intercalation of inorganic ions or small molecules such as NH4 +, H2O and small molecules between MoS2 layers. Furthermore, the intensities of diffraction peaks at 8.9° and 17.5° are gradually decreased in the following order HT5-20 > HT4-20 > HT4-5 > HT2-5. 2H-MoS2 is a typical two-dimensional layered material with a interlayer distance of 0.62 nm. The synthesis process can affect the MoS2 nanostructures including interlayer distance, stacking layers and lateral dimension. Therefore, HRTEM was used to intuitively investigate the microscopical layer structures. As shown in Fig. 2 , all the MoS2 samples synthesized by ball milling of Mc exhibit the interlayer distance of 0.62 nm. MC sample is composed of bulk sheets with lateral sizes of several hundreds of nanometers and stacking layers of more than 15. As the ball milling time prolonging, the stacking layers and the lateral dimension of ball-milled Mc samples are steadily decreased. When the ball milling time is longer than 12 h, the stacking layers and the lateral dimension of obtained ball milled MoS2 samples vary slightly. BM12 and BM16 sample have fewer stacking layers of 6 ∼ 8 and shorter lateral dimension of ∼ 30 nm. Therefore, it can be inferred that the layer structures of BM12 are the limit of Mc with the ball-milling top-down approach. HRTEM images (Fig. 3 ) of MoS2 samples synthesized by hydrothermal method show their interlayer distances of about 1.0 nm. The lateral dimensions and average stacking layer numbers are diverse for MoS2 samples synthesized by hydrothermal method with different Mo and S precursors. From HT5-20 to HT2-5, the lateral dimensions become small, and the stacking layers lessen. The lateral dimension of HT2-5 sample is 5 ∼ 10 nm, and the stacking layers are reduced to 1 ∼ 3. To objectively measure the lateral dimensions and stacking layers of MoS2 samples, we randomly counted 50 MoS2 nanosheets for each MoS2 sample from HRTEM images, and calculated the lateral dimension and average stacking layer numbers. The lateral dimension of HT5-20 and HT4-20 samples is 20 ∼ 40 nm, and that of HT4-5 and HT2-5 samples is 5 ∼ 10 nm. The average stacking layer numbers of HT5-20, HT4-20, HT4-5 and HT2-5 catalysts are 5, 4, 4 and 2, respectively. Compared to pristine and ball-milled Mc sample, HT x-y MoS2 samples have smaller stacking layer numbers and shorter lateral dimensions. The intensity of (002) diffraction peak of 2H-MoS2 is positively correlated with its stacking layers along c axis [40,41]. The intensities of (100) and (110) diffraction peaks of MoS2 have positive correlation with its lateral dimension [42]. After the ball milling of Mc for different times, the decrease of (002), (100) and (110) diffraction peak intensities of the obtained samples means the reduction of stacking layers and the lateral dimension. Ball milling can mechanically cleave the bulk Mc, but the break of Mc is random and uncontrollable. The stacking layers and the lateral dimensions can be reduced by ball milling of Mc. However, increasing the milling time, the milling efficiency decreases, and the Mc particle size including the stacking layers and the lateral dimensions gradually reaches its lamit. When Mc sample was continuously ball-milled exceeding a certain time, the layer structures of obtained MoS2 samples would hardly change, while the decrease of stacking layer number and lateral dimension reach their limits. It can be assumed that MoS2 samples obtained by ball-milling of Mc for more than 12 h can stabilize at its limit lateral size of ca. 30 nm and stacking layers of 6 ∼ 8. The reduced intensities of the diffraction peaks at 8.9° and 17.5° and the broad (100) and (110) diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns of MoS2 samples synthesized by hydrothermal method suggests that the MoS2 samples possess fewer stacking layer and smaller lateral dimensions. The flexible hydrothermal synthesis method with high controllability can accurately construct MoS2 sample with controllable layer structures by adjusting the synthesis parameters. It is obvious that hydrothermal process benefits to generate MoS2 samples with fewer stacking layers and nano-scaled lateral dimension. The bottom-up hydrothermal approach by tuning the Mo and S precursors can construct MoS2 catalysts with layer structures of bilayer and lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm. Summing up the above, the hydrothermal process can successfully achieve the highly controllable synthesis of nano-sized MoS2 nanosheets with low stack. The vibrational spectrum is sensitive to the thickness of MoS2 sample, Raman spectra were collected to further investigate the stacking layers of MoS2 samples. Two representative in-plane E 1 2g and out-of-plane A 1g Raman modes can be observed in MoS2 samples [43]. The frequency difference between E 1 2g and A 1g modes can act as an available diagnostic of the stacking layers of MoS2 materials [44]. As a result, the frequency difference of the two modes decreases with the decrease of stacking layers of MoS2 nanosheets. Fig. 4 gives the Raman spectra of MoS2 samples obtained by ball milling of Mc for different times and hydrothermal method with different Mo and S precursors. For MoS2 catalysts obtained by ball milling of Mc for different times, the slight red and blue shifts can be respectively observed for Raman modes E 1 2g and A 1g in Fig. 4a. The frequency difference between E 1 2g and A 1g modes is decreased slightly for MoS2 sample as the ball milling time prolonged, implying that the stacking layers of MoS2 decrease somewhat. Compared with those of Mc, the red shift of E 1 2g and blue shift of A 1g can be obviously observed for MoS2 catalysts synthesized by hydrothermal method with various Mo and S precursors from Fig. 4b. The frequency difference between E 1 2g and A 1g modes monotonically decreases in the following order: HT5-20 > HT4-20 > HT4-5 > HT2-5. Thus, it can be deduced that the stacking layers of MoS2 nanosheets synthesized with different Mo and S precursors are decreased as follows: HT5-20 > HT4-20 > HT4-5 > HT2-5, that is, HT2-5 sample possesses the fewest stacking layers. The element chemical states of MoS2 materials were further studied by XPS characterization. Fig. 5 gives the XPS spectra of Mo and S elements in Mc and MoS2 samples synthesized with various Mo and S precursors, and the binding energies of Mo 3d and S 2p are summarized in Table 2 . The Mo element is mainly present as Mo4+, and the sulfur element shows S2- for MoS2 samples. Mo 3d XPS spectrum of Mc sample displays two binding energy peaks at 232.3 and 229.1 eV, respectively, corresponding to the Mo 3d3/2 and Mo 3d5/2 binding energy peaks of Mo4+. The Mo 3d binding energies of MoS2 samples synthesized by hydrothermal method shift negatively compared with Mc sample. Mo 3d binding energies of HT2-5 ∼ HT5-20 were 0.7 eV smaller than those of Mc. The S 2p XPS spectrum of Mc sample in Fig. 5b exhibits S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 binding energies are correspondingly 163.2 and 162.0 eV. The S 2p binding energies of MoS2 samples synthesized by hydrothermal method also negatively shift about 0.6 eV with respect to those of Mc. Compared with those of bulk 2H-MoS2 materials, both Mo 3d and S 2p binding energies in HT4-5 ∼ HT5-20 samples shift negatively. In comparison with Mc, mild hydrothermal method endows obtained MoS2 samples with poorer crystallinity and richer defects, hence the Mo 3d binding energies shift negatively. MoS2 samples were synthesized by hydrothermal method possess interlayer intercalated species and fewer stacking layers, thus the van der Waals interactions between S layers become weak, thus the S 2p binding energies also move toward negative direction. The minus shifts of Mo 3d and S 2p binding energies imply the weak electronic interactions between the S-Mo-S atomic layers, which may be caused by their poor crystallinity, intercalated structures and fewer layers of MoS2 samples [19,45,46]. Consequently, nano-scaled MoS2 samples with poor crystallinity and fewer stacking layers can be synthesized by controllable synthesis, and possess more open structure. Furthermore, the interaction forces among layers are poor for the obtained MoS2 samples with open structure, which can provide more adsorption sites for the reactants and stronger interaction with the reactants. 3.2 Catalytic hydrogenation performances of PAHs with MoS2 samples synthesized with ball-milling method and hydrothermal method Asphaltenes are the most aromatic of the heaviest components of heavy oils, and thus they are the most difficult to be hydrogenated. Rapid hydroconvertion of asphaltenes is the critical step for upgrading heavy oils into clean fuels. According to the Yen-Mullins model [14,47], the predominant asphaltene molecular can form asphaltene nanoaggregates by intermolecular forces with aggregation numbers of ∼6. These nanoaggregates can further aggregate, and form clusters of nanoaggregates with aggregation numbers of ∼8. The predominant asphaltene molecular is composed of the aromatic core of fused PAHs, naphthenic, aliphatic side chains, and heteroatoms. Depending on the number of aromatic cores, the asphaltene molecular architectures are generally considered to be “island” model or “archipelago” model [48]. Due to the structure similarity between PAHs and aromatic core in asphaltenes, PAHs including AN, PN and NA with various hydrogenation difficulty can serve as model compounds to investigate the catalytic hydrogenation activities of MoS2 catalysts. The catalytic performance of MoS2 sample was evaluated by the hydrogenation of PAHs in the slurry-phase autoclave reactor. PAHs hydrogenation reactions proceed ring by ring via successive steps. The first-ring hydrogenation of PAHs is favourable kinetically. The hydrogenation rates of subsequent rings turn out to be slower, and the last ring hydrogenation occurs more difficultly in comparison with the first ring hydrogenation. Take anthracene for example, AN can first hydrogenate into preliminary AH2, and this reaction is kinetically very easy even without catalyst. However, AH2 hydrogenation into AH4, AH8, and AH14 successively become more and more difficult. Under the experiment conditions of this work, the conversions of AN over synthesized MoS2 catalysts are higher than 90.0%, but the hydrogenation degree of each catalyst is different. The catalytic activities of MoS2 catalysts obtained by ball-milling of Mc for different times were given in Fig. 6 . From Fig. 6a, compared with Mc catalyst, when the ball milling time of Mc catalyst is prolonged to 12 h, the obtained MoS2 catalysts give gradually improved conversions and HP of AN. Further prolonging the ball milling time of Mc to 16 h, the conversion and HP over obtained BM16 catalyst exhibit no significant improvement. From Fig. 6b, the dominate products of AN hydrogenation for all the catalysts are preliminary products AH2 and AH4. As prolonging the ball milling time to 12 h, the obtained MoS2 catalysts demonstrate progressive increase of the selectivity to deep hydrogenation product AH8. When the ball milling time is further prolonged from 12 h to 16 h, the selectivity to AH8 for AN hydrogenation over BM16 catalyst remains unchanged. The catalytic activities of MoS2 catalysts obtained by ball milling of Mc are in the following order: BM16 = BM12 > BM8 > BM4 > BM2 > Mc. BM16 displays the highest HP of 30.3% and the highest selectivity to AH8 of 24.1%. From Fig. 6c, the conversions of AN hydrogenation with each catalyst synthesized by hydrothermal method with different Mo and S precursors are all very high and close to 100 %. However, HPs differ greatly for all the MoS2 catalysts. HP of AN for HT1 catalyst is 56.8%, which is about 3.0 times of that for HT5-20 catalyst. Selectivity of AN hydrogenation products is displayed in Fig. 6d. AH2 was the main product when HT5-20 was adopted as the hydrogenation catalyst. AH2 can be totally hydrogenated into deep hydrogenation product with HT2-5 catalyst. AN hydrogenation with HT2-5 and HT4-5 catalyst can produce 85.84% and 71.06% of deeply hydrogenated products AH8, respectively. Besides, 5.24% and 2.04% of fully hydrogenated product AH14 can be detected when HT2-5 and HT4-5 catalyst was adopted respectively. Consequently, the catalytic hydrogenation activities of MoS2 catalysts synthesized by hydrothermal method are as follows: HT5-20 < HT4-20 < HT4-5 < HT2-5. MoS2 catalysts synthesized by hydrothermal method with different Mo and S precursors were further used to catalyze the hydrogenation of PAH compound models PN and NA, which is more difficult to be hydrogenated than AN. The conversions of both PN and NA hydrogenation over HT5-20 to HT2-5 catalysts in Fig. 7 a and 7c are also increased as the following order: HT5-20 < HT4-20 < HT4-5 < HT2-5. The PN conversion for HT2-5 catalyst is 68.9%, which is 4.2 times that of HT5-20 catalyst. HT2-5 catalyst has the highest NA hydrogenation conversion of 68.2%, which is 14.1 times of that for HT5-20 catalyst. From HT5-20 to HT2-5 catalyst, the selectivities to deep hydrogenation products of PH8 and PH14 are increased in sequence in Fig. 7b, especially, the selectivities to PH8 and PH14 for HT2-5 catalyst can reach respectively as high as 32.0 % and 8.2 %. The results of catalytic PN hydrogenation confirm that HT2-5 catalyst exhibits higher catalytic activities. As shown in Fig. 7d, the selectivity to NH4 over HT5-20 catalyst is 90.5%, but 9.5% of HYC can be detected. For HT2-5 catalyst, the selectivity to NH4 is 98.3%, and 1.0% of NH10 can be detected. Furthermore, negligible amount of HYC can be detected in the NA hydrogenation products with HT2-5 catalyst. The results of catalytic NA hydrogenation further confirm that HT2-5 catalyst with the smallest lateral dimension and the fewest stacking layers exhibits the highest catalytic activities of both PN and NA hydrogenation. The catalytic activities of PN and NA hydrogenation for MoS2 catalysts synthesized by hydrothermal method show the same order with those of AN hydrogenation. MoS2 catalysts with smaller lateral dimension and fewer stacking layers demonstrate better catalytic hydrogenation performance. From the above results, it can be concluded that herein developed MoS2 catalysts can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of heavy oil model compounds AN, PN and NA. 3.3 The structure–activity relationship between MoS2 samples and catalytic hydrogenation of PAHs Bulk MoS2 materials possess layered structures in which one layer is composed of chemically bonded S − Mo − S atomic triplanes and the stacking of adjacent layers depends on the weak van der Waals interactions. Obviously, to break bulk MoS2 materials into nanomaterials, the in-plane chemical bonds and interlayer van der Waals interactions have to be destroyed. Ball millingcan generate two forces on layered materials to slice them into thin and shortnanosheets.The shear force and compression force can respectively cleave the exterior surfaces and the edges of layered materials [49–51]. Consequently, ball-milling can pulverize bulk two-dimensional layered materials by breaking the interlayer van der Waals interactions and the in-plane chemical bonds. Evidently the lateral size and stacking layers of MoS2 can be gradually reduced with boosting ball-milling time. After sufficient ball-milling time, the pulverization to bulk materials will reached its limit, and the layer structures will keep constant with further milling. From the results of characterizations and catalytic activities, it can be found that ball milling can pulverize bulk Mc catalysts into thin and short MoS2 sheets with prolonging the ball milling time of Mc, thus improve the catalytic hydrogenation activity for the ball-milled Mc catalyst. However, when the ball milling time of Mc exceeds 12 h, the adjustment for the lateral size and stacking layers of Mc reaches its limit, and the catalytic hydrogenation activity for obtained MoS2 catalyst levels off at AN HP of 30.3%. Correspondingly, through the ball milling, bulk materials can be tailored into thin and short MoS2, but the stacking layers and lateral sizes is far from satisfactory. In comparison with the physical ball milling process, the wet chemical hydrothermal synthesis is a more flexible approach through the chemical reaction of Mo and S precursors. In the hydrothermal process, more synthesis parameters can be tuned to control the reaction rate, nucleation and crystallization process. The crystallinity, particle size and nanostructures can be accurately constructed by the bottom-up hydrothermal process. MoS2 materials with various nanostructures tend to demonstrate various physical and chemical properties. Consequently, adjusting the synthesis conditions can synthesize the MoS2 with various structures, and thus improve the property of MoS2. The hydrothermal process with different Mo and S precursors can control the nucleus formation and crystallization of MoS2 catalysts, hence the layer structures of MoS2 nanosheets can be regulated. Combining the results of characterizations and the catalytic activities of MoS2 catalyst synthesized by hydrothermal method in Table 3 , the layer structures of MoS2 nanosheets can be well correlated with its layer structures, and have no direct correlations with their BET surface areas. As shown in Table 3, MoS2 catalysts HT4-20 and HT4-5 have the same average stacking layer number and different lateral sizes, the catalytic hydrogenation activity is higher for MoS2 catalyst HT4-5 with smaller lateral size. Moreover, MoS2 catalysts HT5-20 and HT4-20 (or HT4-5 and HT2-5) possess the same lateral size and different average stacking layer numbers, MoS2 catalysts HT4-20 or HT2-5 with smaller average stacking layer number exhibit higher catalytic hydrogenation activities. HT2-5 catalyst with the fewest stacking layers of 2 and smallest lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm shows the highest activity of catalytic hydrogenation. Besides, from Table 3, it can be found that the catalytic hydrogenation activities of MoS2 catalysts have no direct correlation with its physical property BET surface areas. For MoS2 materials, the BET surface area results from the exposure of the basal plane (001) and edge plane (100). But the basal plane often contributes much more surface area than edge plane, and it possesses excellent lubricating properties and photocatalytic activities [26]. Thus, the BET surface areas may not decide the catalytic hydrogenation activity of MoS2 catalyst. Scheme 2 presents the layer structures of MoS2 catalysts and the rim-edge model for the active sites. As shown in Scheme 2a, MoS2 catalysts with smaller lateral size can expose more edges, and demonstrate higher catalytic hydrogenation activity, when MoS2 catalysts possess the same stacking layer number. Scheme 2a indicates that the catalytic hydrogenation active sites of MoS2 catalysts indeed locate at the exposed edges. Besides, Scheme 2b manifests that MoS2 catalysts with the same lateral size and different stacking layer numbers display the same amounts of exposed edges, but MoS2 catalysts with fewer stacking layers exhibit better catalytic hydrogenation performance. That is to say, not all the exposed edges of S-Mo-S atomic layers act as active sites of catalytic hydrogenation, but only partial edges of MoS2 layers serve as the catalytic active sites for PAHs hydrogenation. The decrease of lateral size and stacking layers can absolutely increase the exposed edges of top and bottom S-Mo-S atomic layers. Consequently, it can be speculated that the edges of the top layer and bottom layer are active centers for catalytic hydrogenation, and the edge sites of interior layers have no or few contributions to the catalytic hydrogenation activity for MoS2 catalyst. MoS2 catalyst with the smallest lateral size and stacking layer number of 2 exposes the maximum edges of top and bottom S-Mo-S atomic layers, and demonstrates the optimized catalytic activity for PAHs hydrogenation. The above results of active sites for the catalytic hydrogenation over MoS2 catalysts are consistent with the rim-edge model for the desulfurization over MoS2 catalyst proposed by Chianelli et al. For the rim-edge model in Scheme 2c [40,52], rim sites exist at the edges of exterior layers of MoS2 sheets with adjacent basal planes exposing to the reaction medium, and are active for both hydrogenation and desulfurization reactions. Edge sites of MoS2 sheets locate at the edges of interior layers without exposed basal planes, and they are only reactive for desulfurization reaction. However, for the catalytic hydrogenation reaction of PAHs in this work, the edge sites of MoS2 catalyst exhibit no or few contributions to the catalytic hydrogenation, and more exposed rim sites are essential to efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of PAHs. The relative ratio of rim sites (R%) for MoS2 sheets can be deduced in Eq. (8) as follows: (8) R % = R / R + E × 100 = 2 / n × 100 Where R is the number of rim sites, E is the number of edge sites, and n is the stacking layer number. The relative ratios R% for HT5-20, HT4-20, HT4-5 and HT4-2 catalysts are 40%, 50%, 50% and 100%, respectively. Hence bilayer and single-layer MoS2 catalysts can expose 100% of active sites for the catalytic hydrogenation. The ratio of rim sites is negatively correlated with the stacking layers of MoS2 catalysts, but has no relationship with the lateral size. However, the absolute amounts of rim sites are also negatively correlated with lateral size and the stacking layers of MoS2 sheets. For the same weight amount of MoS2 catalyst, small lateral size can contribute more rim sites, thus MoS2 catalyst with smaller lateral size can provide more active sites for catalytic hydrogenation reaction. The rim sites of MoS2 catalysts often can be classified into two different types of edges named Mo- and S-edges [53]. It has been reported that the hydrogen can adsorb on the edges of MoS2, and then dissociate into hydrogen atoms bonding to S2− anions or Mo atom to form acidic SH groups and metal-hydride species [54,55]. However, it is proposed that metal-hydride species (e.g. Mo − H) are not thermodynamically favored. Hence after the initial H2 dissociation, the hydride species can reacts with the adjacent sulfur anions to generate additional SH groups [56,57]. The transition states and activation energies for molecular hydrogen dissociation and surface migration of atomic hydrogen can occur on the edge planes of MoS2 catalysts.[58] The same type of SH species is stable at the surface of nanocrystalline MoS2, independent of the preparation conditions and of the presence of a second metal (Co, Ni, Pt). No tangible difference between the structures presumably exposing M- and S-edges could be identified.[59] Therefore, the hydrogen dissociation on the edges of MoS2 is not the rate-determining step in the hydrogenation reaction, and both rim sites and edge sites can activate H2. Being planar molecules with π-bonding, PAHs can adsorb on the basal plane of MoS2 in parallel by strong van der Waals interactions according to DFT calculations and STM studies [60–62]. Hydrogenation is likely to occur at regions located at the edges of the basal planes, where SH groups provide hydrogen. Hence, only activated H species at the rim sites can react with PAHs adsorbing on the basal plane [63]. Due to the space constraints, it is difficult for activated H species at edge sites to react with PAHs. Correspondingly, the rim sites can activate H2, meanwhile, favor to the reaction between activated H species and PAHs molecules due to its accessibility. As the hydrogenation of PAHs proceeds, the deep hydrogenation products are nonplanar. Compared with edge sites, steric hindrance effect of large molecule for rim sites are much smaller [64,65]. Besides, PAHs can adsorb on the whole basal plane, however, it may be only the PAH molecular at the edges of the basal planes, which is close to rim sites, can react with SH- at rim sites to hydrogenate. The adsorbed PAH moleculars on the positions far away from the rim sites can not react with SH-. Thus rim sites are beneficial to the adsorption of PAHs and desorption of corresponding products during the catalytic hydrogenation process. Consequently, aiming at the catalytic hydrogenation, it is an effective strategy to enhance the exposure of active sites for catalytic hydrogenation by constructing MoS2 catalyst with minimum lateral size and without edge sites, that is to say, MoS2 catalysts with smaller lateral size and bilayers or single layer. Therefore, the highest activity of AN hydrogenation for HT2-5 catalyst can be ascribed to its higher exposure of active sites, which results from its fewer stacking layers of 2 and smallest lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm. 4 Conclusions Both top-down ball-milling method and bottom-up hydrothermal method can successfully synthesize MoS2 catalysts with expected edge exposures by tuning the layer structures of MoS2 catalysts. The adjustment of stacking layers and lateral sizes for MoS2 catalysts by ball-milling method is limited to stacking layers of 6 ∼ 8 and lateral sizes of ca. 30 nm. In comparison with ball-milling method, the hydrothermal method can construct MoS2 with smaller lateral sizes and fewer stacking layers, especially, HT2-5 catalyst fabricated with ATTM as Mo and S precursor possesses average stacking layers of 2 and lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm. MoS2 catalysts can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of various PAH model compounds, and the catalytic activities of PAH hydrogenation for MoS2 catalysts depend on their layer structures. The edges of top and bottom S-Mo-S atomic layer for MoS2 sheets are positively correlated with active sites for catalytic hydrogenation of PAHs. The highest catalytic activity of HT2-5 catalyst results from its layer structures with 100% rim sites and the smallest lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm, which benefits to expose maximum active sites for catalytic hydrogenation reactions. This work can help us to profoundly understand the active sites of catalytic hydrogenation, and provide the valuable guidance for the development of highly active hydrogenation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Slurry-phase hydrogenation technology is the frontier topic in the efficient conversion of heavy oils into light fractions around the world. Developing highly active dispersed MoS2 catalysts is the major obstacle to realize the industrial application of upgrading heavy oils. In this work, both top-down ball-milling method and bottom-up hydrothermal method were designed to synthesize MoS2 catalysts with controllable layer structures. The stacking layers and lateral sizes for micro-scaled MoS2 catalysts by ball-milling method can be reduced to their limits and stabilize at 6 ∼ 8 layers and lateral size of ca. 30 nm. The more flexible bottom-up hydrothermal method can construct MoS2 catalysts with much smaller lateral sizes and fewer stacking layers, especially, MoS2 catalyst fabricated with ammonium tetrathiomolybdate as Mo and S precursor possesses average stacking layers of 2 and lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons anthracene, phenanthrene and naphthalene were used as model compounds of heavy oils to investigate the catalytic hydrogenation performance of designed MoS2 catalysts. The catalytic activities of MoS2 catalysts can be well correlated with their stacking layers and lateral size. The edges of top and bottom S-Mo-S atomic layers for MoS2 sheets, named rim sites, are positively correlated with the exposure of active sites for catalytic hydrogenation of PAHs. The highest catalytic activity of MoS2 catalyst results from its layer structures of 100% rim sites and the smallest lateral size of 5 ∼ 10 nm, which is beneficial to expose maximum active sites for catalytic hydrogenation reactions. This work can guide us to design the highly active hydrogenation catalysts, and promote the industrial application of upgrading heavy oils.
